description: snowy landscape with mountains at top; bridge in URQ; trees at left and bottom; two figures at bottom, wearing wide-brimmed hats and furs--one man in boat at bottom center/right, warming his hands at a small stove; second man in LLC holding a vessel with a handle; off-white mount; dark-finished wooden roller ends
inscription:
Juchao Ye Guang 居巢葉廣 (“Ye Guang, nest-dweller”)。

Artist’s seal: 
Ye Guang zhiyin 葉廣之印 (“Ye Guang’s seal”), Yuan Bo 元博
text:
The winter scenery surrounding the river in this painting is depicted using the so-called reverse saturation method, meaning that the background, including the sky and the river, are painted with light ink, while other areas, including the mountains, riverbank, treetops, and the boat itself etc. are left unpainted. This gives the impression that these spots are covered with snow. The depiction of the fishmen is vivid. Especially noteworthy is the subtle and very skillful rendition of smoke rising above the frozen river from the charcoal brazier on board the river skiff.

Fishermen are popular subjects in Chinese painting, and depictions of them fall into two genres: paintings of recluses in the guise of fishermen who have withdrawn from society and live on boats in secluded environments, and paintings of real fishermen, such as this one. In compositions depicting the lives of fishermen, the fishermen are generally shown at work, as carefree people who, when their work is done, can spend their time at leisure and enjoying nature. The theme of “fisherman-recluse” (known as yuyin, “reclusion in a fishing boat”), however, concerns eremitism rather than fishing. Those seen on boats are not fishermen but scholar-recluses who are escaping an official career, fame and other social burdens.
title: Fishing on Winter River
